channel.title: botar's old time radio
channel.itunes:author: www.botar.us
channel.description: we deliver the best of old time radio shows to your door fresh daily. shows like the shadow, fibber mcgee and molly, boston blackie, the green hornet, X-minus one plus so much more.
channel.itunes:subtitle: OTR by botar
channel.itunes:summary: old time radio shows from the 30s 40s and 50s delivered fresh to your door daily.

item.title: challenge of the yukon, wolf cub 06/12/1947
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: Trapper Dave Ferguson adopts Slash, a nearly dead wolf cub. Years later, the wolf returns the favor.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/12/1947
item.itunes:summary: Challenge of the Yukon was a radio series that began on Detroits station WXYZ. The series was first heard on February 3, 1938. The program was an adventure series about Sergeant William Preston of the NorthWest Mounted Police and his lead alaskan husky sled dog, Yukon King, as they fought evildoers in the Northern wilderness during the Gold Rush of the 1890s.
item.itunes:keywords: challenge of the yukon,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: jungle jim, episode 331, hunt for A U boat 02/28/1942
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: jungle jim, episode 331
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/28/1942
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: great gildersleeve, episode 361, marjories wedding gown 04/19/1950
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A wedding dress for Marjorie. Several of them in fact.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/19/1950
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: lum and abner, circus moves to belleville 04/01/1935
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: The circus has lost over 100 dollars and is moving to Belleville. But the boys need 200 dollars for a license to operate the show from this town.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 04/01/1935
item.itunes:summary: Lum and Abner was an American network radio comedy program that was aired from 1931 to 1954. Modeled on life in the small town of Waters, Arkansas, the show proved immensely popular. In 1936, Waters changed its name to Pine Ridge after the shows fictional town.
item.itunes:keywords: lum and abner,pine ridge,botar,OTR,old time radio

item.title: dragnet, big will 06/12/1956
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: dragnet
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/12/1956
item.itunes:summary: Dragnet, the brainchild of Jack Webb, may very well be the most well remembered, and the best, radio police drama series. From September, 1949 through February 1957, Dragnets 30 minute shows, broadcast on NBC, brought to radio true police stories in a low key, documentary style.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1387 mystery of the stolen costume p11 03/24/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/24/1948
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/16/1953
item.itunes:summary: Frontier Town, First air date March 5, 1949, the saga of the roaring West. Here is the Adventure Story of the Early West, the tamed and the untamed, from Cheyenne to Calgary, from Dodge City to Poker Flats. These are the towns they fought to live in and lived to fight for, teeming crucibles of pioneer freedom.
item.itunes:keywords: frontier town,western,dodge city,poker flats,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: the whistler, murder in paradise 11/28/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: An excon piano player goes to work at a resort owned by a tough gambler, and promptly falls for the owners wife. A knife fight and an auto wreck complicate the romance.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/28/1948
item.itunes:summary: The Whistler was one of American radios most popular mystery dramas, with a 13 year run from May 16, 1942 until September 22, 1955.

item.title: mr president, theodore roosevelt 08/07/1947
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: A boxing Mr. President faces a crises with the Germans off the coast of Venezuela.
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/07/1947
item.itunes:summary: This old time radio series tells the untold tales the Commanders in chiefs everyday life. In order to challenge the audience to guess his identity, the Presidents name was not revealed until the end of the show.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1373 kingdom under the sea p12 03/04/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/04/1948
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1365 kingdom under the sea p4 02/23/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/23/1948
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:summary: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is a true radio serial classic produced by George Edwards, a well known Australian radio personality. Telling the Robert Louis Stevensons classic tale of a man divided, this fifteen minute serial debuted in 1943, running for 52 episodes. The intense pacing of each episode as well as the high quality production values and the talented voice acting of George Edwards and the rest of the cast make this a must have for any fan of classic radio.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1358 batmans great mystery p9 02/13/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/13/1948
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:summary: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is a true radio serial classic produced by George Edwards, a well known Australian radio personality. Telling the Robert Louis Stevensons classic tale of a man divided, this fifteen minute serial debuted in 1943, running for 52 episodes. The intense pacing of each episode as well as the high quality production values and the talented voice acting of George Edwards and the rest of the cast make this a must have for any fan of classic radio.

Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1352 batmans great mystery p3 02/05/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/05/1948
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: visit the trelor family
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/13/1944
item.itunes:summary: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is a true radio serial classic produced by George Edwards, a well known Australian radio personality. Telling the Robert Louis Stevensons classic tale of a man divided, this fifteen minute serial debuted in 1943, running for 52 episodes. The intense pacing of each episode as well as the high quality production values and the talented voice acting of George Edwards and the rest of the cast make this a must have for any fan of classic radio.

item.title: gunsmoke, letter of the law 06/18/1961
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: gunsmoke
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 06/18/1961
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1347 dead mans secret p12 01/29/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/29/1948
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/06/1944
item.itunes:summary: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is a true radio serial classic produced by George Edwards, a well known Australian radio personality. Telling the Robert Louis Stevensons classic tale of a man divided, this fifteen minute serial debuted in 1943, running for 52 episodes. The intense pacing of each episode as well as the high quality production values and the talented voice acting of George Edwards and the rest of the cast make this a must have for any fan of classic radio.

item.title: gunsmoke, mas justice 05/07/1961
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: gunsmoke
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 05/07/1961
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.itunes:summary: Challenge of the Yukon was a radio series that began on Detroits station WXYZ. The series was first heard on February 3, 1938. item.title: jungle jim, episode 308, sasha investigates 09/27/1941
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: jungle jim, episode 309
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 09/27/1941
item.itunes:summary: This fifteen minute juvenile adventure show, based on the Alex Raymond comic strip in Hearsts Comic Weekly, was broadcast on a weekly basis for many years. Week by week it followed the trials and tribulations of Jungle Jim Bradley, the intrepid adventurer. Interestingly, the first episode of the series not only continued the story line of Flash Gordon, which was another Hearst strip, but also used the same theme music.

item.title: great gildersleeve, episode 340, jolly boys band 11/23/1949

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/23/1949
item.itunes:summary: The Great Gildersleeve 1941 to 1957, was one of broadcast historys earliest spinoff programs. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.itunes:summary: Lum and Abner was an American network radio comedy program that was aired from 1931 to 1954. Modeled on life in the small town of Waters, Arkansas, the show proved immensely popular. In 1936, Waters changed its name to Pine Ridge after the shows fictional town.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1341 dead mans secret p6 01/21/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/21/1948
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/27/1943
item.itunes:summary: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is a true radio serial classic produced by George Edwards, a well known Australian radio personality. Telling the Robert Louis Stevensons classic tale of a man divided, this fifteen minute serial debuted in 1943, running for 52 episodes. The intense pacing of each episode as well as the high quality production values and the talented voice acting of George Edwards and the rest of the cast make this a must have for any fan of classic radio.

item.title: gunsmoke, no indians 03/26/1961
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: gunsmoke
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 03/26/1961
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.itunes:summary: Challenge of the Yukon was a radio series that began on Detroits station WXYZ. The series was first heard on February 3, 1938. Throckmorton Philharmonic Gildersleeve, was a character who had been a staple on Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve enjoyed its greatest success in the 1940s. item.title: adventures of superman, ep1335 hunger inc p12 01/13/1948
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/13/1948
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: dr jekyll and mr hyde, hyde interupts 12/16/1943
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: hyde interupts
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/16/1943
item.itunes:summary: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is a true radio serial classic produced by George Edwards, a well known Australian radio personality. Telling the Robert Louis Stevensons classic tale of a man divided, this fifteen minute serial debuted in 1943, running for 52 episodes. The intense pacing of each episode as well as the high quality production values and the talented voice acting of George Edwards and the rest of the cast make this a must have for any fan of classic radio.

item.title: gunsmoke, daddy 02/12/1961
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: gunsmoke
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 02/12/1961
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

Actor Harold Peary played the character during its transition from the parent show into the spinoff and later in a quartet of feature films released at the height of the shows popularity.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1329 hunger inc p6 01/05/1947
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/05/1947
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.title: dr jekyll and mr hyde, lost in mountains 12/06/1943
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: lost in mountains
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/06/1943
item.itunes:summary: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is a true radio serial classic produced by George Edwards, a well known Australian radio personality. Telling the Robert Louis Stevensons classic tale of a man divided, this fifteen minute serial debuted in 1943, running for 52 episodes. The intense pacing of each episode as well as the high quality production values and the talented voice acting of George Edwards and the rest of the cast make this a must have for any fan of classic radio.

item.title: gunsmoke, spring term 01/01/1961
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: spring term
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 01/01/1961
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1315 pennies for plunder p13 12/15/1947
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/15/1947
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: in coravina austria
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/25/1943
item.itunes:summary: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is a true radio serial classic produced by George Edwards, a well known Australian radio personality. Telling the Robert Louis Stevensons classic tale of a man divided, this fifteen minute serial debuted in 1943, running for 52 episodes. The intense pacing of each episode as well as the high quality production values and the talented voice acting of George Edwards and the rest of the cast make this a must have for any fan of classic radio.

item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.title: adventures of superman, ep1310 pennies for plunder p8 12/08/1947
item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: adventures of superman
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 12/08/1947
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:summary: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is a true radio serial classic produced by George Edwards, a well known Australian radio personality. Telling the Robert Louis Stevensons classic tale of a man divided, this fifteen minute serial debuted in 1943, running for 52 episodes. The intense pacing of each episode as well as the high quality production values and the talented voice acting of George Edwards and the rest of the cast make this a must have for any fan of classic radio.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 10/09/1960
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/28/1947
item.itunes:summary:
The Adventures of Superman, adapted from the DC Comics character created in 1938, came to radio as a syndicated show on New York Citys WOR on February 12, 1940. On Mutual, it was broadcast from August 31, 1942 to June 17, 1949, as a weekly serial. It was aired on a three-times-a-week schedule from January 31, 1949 to June 17, 1949. The series shifted to ABC Saturday mornings on November 5 1949, and then to twice-a-week in June, 1950, continuing on ABC until March 1, 1951.
The character created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster arrived on radio not long after the comic book and took on an added dimension with Bud Collyer in the title role. During World War II and the post-war years, the juvenile adventure radio serial, sponsored by Kelloggs Pep, was a huge success, with many listeners following the quest for -truth, justice and the American way- in the daily radio broadcasts, the comic book stories and the newspaper comic strip.
item.itunes:keywords: adventures of superman,dc comics,OTR,old time radio,botar

item.itunes:author: www.botar.us
item.description: hettie rescued again
item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 11/04/1943
item.itunes:summary: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is a true radio serial classic produced by George Edwards, a well known Australian radio personality. Telling the Robert Louis Stevensons classic tale of a man divided, this fifteen minute serial debuted in 1943, running for 52 episodes. The intense pacing of each episode as well as the high quality production values and the talented voice acting of George Edwards and the rest of the cast make this a must have for any fan of classic radio.

item.title: gunsmoke, tumbleweed 08/28/1960

item.itunes:subtitle: original air date 08/28/1960
item.itunes:summary: Airing on the CBS network on April 26, 1952, Gunsmoke was the first and greatest adult Western, it told the story of the violence that moved west with young America, and the story of a man who moved with it. That man was Matt Dillon, U.S. Marshal of Dodge City, Kansas. In Dodge, Dillon was surrounded by hardened, but heartfelt, townsfolk, including his deputy, Chester Wesley Proudfoot; the town physician and mortician, Dr. Charles Adams and, the owner of the Long Branch Saloon, Miss Kitty Russell.
